review_body: Very good location; not too expensive; very clean; small room (no closet) and somewhat too warm; staff speaks rather poor English but very kind; nice café with western breakfast in the hall; good WiFi in room.

3min walk to nishi Shinjuku train station and 10min by foot to shinjuku station. Affortable hotel with restaurant nearby.Basic toilet amenities are available at lobby, wifi available in room. Router will be provided upon check in.Staffs are friendly and helpful and speak decent English

The rooms were certainly clean but they were VERY small for the cost. Even though we were in a non-smoking area, the fact that smoking was allowed in some areas of the motel ensured that the smell was noticeable throughout the motel, obviously more in some areas than others. Some of the staff were reasonably fluent in English which was certainly of benefit. The venue was close to both suburban and inter-city rail which certainly convenient.

Very nice staff, clean room, including everething you need (They even have massage machine for the foot, its wonderfull after a very busy day)I like small cafe on the first floor. It is better to have wifi in the room, but it is only in the first floor. Thank you, I really relaxed in this Hotel=)

Clean hotel and friendly staff. Like most hotels in Japan, the room size was small but cozy. The side we were on faces the wall of the building next door so don't expect a view. The hardest part was finding this hotel since the name is in Japanese. Downstairs you'll find a nice little cafe and restaurant next door. The Nishi Shinjuku station is right across the street and that's a big plus. There's also a 100 yen store down the street.

After the last place we stayed, this hotel felt like the Park Hyatt. The rooms are adequately sized and the beds are fairly comfortable. The pillows are a combo of the Japanese Marble Pillow and the regular 'fluffy' pillow (so you can pick which you prefer). There's enough space to open up 2 large bags and still move around. Bathrooms can actually fit people over 6', which is a massive bonus. It's noisy outside if you open the window (for cool air), but once the window is closed you hear nothing.The staff are friendly, but their english isn't great (like everywhere in Japan) and there's free wifi in the room.We would stay here again.

Just a 5-7 min walk from shinjuku station (west exit) this hotel is well located and is clean and neat. Rooms are small and check in a late 3pm but this seems to be the norm in Tokyo. We are coming back!

This hotel was in convenient location close to Shinjuku station. I stayed in a twin with a friend and while the room was small, it was larger than expected for a Japanese hotel room. We both brought 24" suitcases, which fit fine, but anything larger would have been difficult to store. The hotel laundry facilities are inexpensive and automatically dispense detergent , so that can help with the lack of space. There is a women-only laundry with a vending machine on the top floor. The beds were firm and the pillows were dual pillows with the Japanese style pillow on one side and a feather pillow on another. The toilet had all the bells and whistles you would expect. The room also came with a fridge, tv, kettle, bath, and foot massager. Food options are fairly good. We ate near the hotel several nights because the weather was bad. There is an inexpensive chain cafe in the lobby that has good croissants and other pastries, and I believe the yakitori restaurant downstairs offers a buffet. We did not try the buffet. The yakitori restaurant is a standard izakaya-type eating establishment. On the other side of the building was a yakiniku/Korean BBQ place. The main downside was that the AC was off and the room got hot fairly quickly during the day. We stayed in late October and it was still too warm for heat. We had the wall view, which kept the room fairly quiet when the window was open. Unfortunately, it did not open very far.

Excellent location close to Shinjuku shopping and loads of small restaurants. Small, but convenient room, free internet, excellent Japanese breakfast (there was also western breakfast, but I didn't´t try it). The only problem was the air conditioning - the room got too warm very quickly so it was really unusable. But it was OK without A/C and it was possible to open the window a little.

Great location, very friendly staff who are very helpful with recommendations. I have booked another night there when i return to Tokyo. Rooms are bigger than average and had fridge, tv, kettle and BATH ;)

Typical Japanese hotel room with plastic moulded bathroom and small double sized bed. Room overlooked the wall of a building but the alternative was to be facing the busy road. It was a good location on the West side of Shinjuku Subway approximately 10min walk, when all the action is on the East side. The beds were a bit hard and if you had large luggage it would be challenging to fit it in the room. The staff were quite friendly and there is a good cafe downstairs and 7eleven several doors down. There are eating places around but they seem geared more for the lunch time business crowd. The price is somewhat a bit high given other locations we stayed at in Tokyo, but that's to be expected of the popular Shinjuku location.

I traveled by myself in early October 2013. I wanted a clean, safe hotel for a single female. This hotel was very welcoming. Some of the staff couldn't speak english, but they certainly tried their best to help me! They would find other staff that could speak english better. The breakfast buffet in the basement was a traditional japanese buffet breakfast. It was definitely worth the JPY1000, considering most things are quite expensive in Tokyo. The Maruonchi (red) subway line is only 2 minutes away and less busy than going to the Shinjuku train station, which was about a 10 minute walk. There are multiple convenience stores near the hotel, which is convenient if you need a beverage late at night. If you're looking for a no frills hotel, this is the place to stay. Don't expect much, it is a basic hotel, but you can use the savings on dinners and shopping b/c there is a lot of that in Tokyo. The rooms are small, but you don't spend all day in the hotel....just for sleeping, so that is fine As reference, I would stay at these chains in the US and Canada (Fairmont, JW Marriott, Marriott, Sheraton, boutique-ish hotels), so you have an idea of the type of hotel I would stay at. I would stay at this hotel again if i was traveling alone.

Stayed for 3 nights at the end of my two week tour around Japan.Great stay:- very helpful staff at reception. One of the men at reception was so kind hailing a cab for me when the typhoon hit - we has drenched from the rain and wind and broken umbrella, yet still persisted in hailing a cab. Great personalised assistance in setting up the wifi router when it wasn't working. Nothing was too much trouble for any of the staff - always happy and going out of their way to help, even if sometimes language was a barrier. On the whole this was't a problem at all.- the rooms are incredibly clean, spacious (for Japan standards), and the bathroom spacious and spotless- I requested a room on a higher floor (level 10) and it was so quiet - really restful sleep and stay- great complimentary bathroom accessories you could collect yourself in the lobby included Shiseido make up remover oil - absolutely loved this!!!- great location - coffee shop in the lobby a great breakfast spotThanks for a great stay!

Rooms are clean and fully equipped. You can even pick up any toiletries you have forgotten to pack when you are going to take the elevator.Beds are on the hard side but quality of sleep is still very good, with its quiet surroundings.Wifi is free (just borrow a router from the front desk).Front desk service is helpful and friendly.The hidden treasure is actually the yakitori restaurant at basement level. Offers very affordable yakitori and drinks. Even cheaper than what you can find outside along the streets.The location is good, with it being very near Nishinjuku station. Only complaint I have is that it takes 10 mins to walk from the hotel to the main Shinjuku station. But on the bright side, use that to burn some calories from all the good food!

It is a nice and a quiet hotel near Shinyuku Station with several Subway lines and several private railways. So the hotel is a good place for starting of tours and for discovering of Tokyo and their surroundings.The staff is friendly and the rooms are clean. I was alone and I had a very small room. I didn´t have any problems but if you are two people perhaps you try to get a bigger room.Around the hotel there are shops for food and drinks, small restaurants and a fastfood restaurant (McDonalds). The next time I´ll book for the same hotel.

we love our stay. its a reasonable size double room with all you need tea making sleep gowns slippers hair brush toothpaste brushes. very clean deep bathtube.no breakfast including but easy to find something to eat nearby.walking distance to shinjuku jr station and highway bus terminal even with luggage.

Nishitetsu Inn ShinjukuGreat location very easy walk from train station and metro even with luggage.—(caution—if you have never been Tokyo—the train stations are really intense and confusing - remember- specifically which exit of the station is closest to your hotel.) When in doubt—head for a ticket information booth- folks are always helpful- but as normal very little English.Rooms are very clean and very adequate size.  Front desk was allways very helpful-- each shift has folks that speak different levels of English but they always find a way to answer your questions and as always inn Japan very polite… We went to the Robot Restaurantone evening(a must visit in Tokyo) the front desk provided us with discount coupons and called the restaurant to make our reservationsInternet is available in the lobby- they provide a gadget that you use to get Wi-Fi in your room- its free you just have to ask for it and hook it up.There is a restaurant but we didn’t visit. In the lobby is a coffee shop that offers pastries etc. Great place to get a snack and do some people watching.Used the laundry service twice- in by 10 out by 7 no problems. There are also laundry service on the 7th and 14 floors.Just for basics and late night snacks there is a Seven eleven out the front doors to the left and a McDonalds right across the street that is open 24-7. Also a variety of restaurants primarily the direction of the train station.Would highly recommend as a base while exploring the city.

Nice place to stay. Subway train is a few minutes walk away. Plenty of food and convenience stores around the vicinity. Very near to Hilton hotel for convenient pickup for airport buses and local tours. Room may be considered as small by international standards. Value for money.

It's a really great hotel with clean room, English speaker staff, convinient location to subway, train station and Shijuku. The room will provide you a bottle of water for free if you chose not change your bed sheet which is really good for enviroment. I left my luggage in the hotel overnight for free to cause I was traveling in Kawaguchiko. I had a great time in this hotel and would love to recommend it to others.

Overall, Nishitetsu Inn is located in a very good area. Nearby the train station and Convienience stores. And it should take 10 minutes to walk to Shinjuku.Their service is very good. They helped out a lot. The price is considered cheap as well. The room and the hotel itself is very clean.It is reccommended for anyone to stay in.

First trip to Tokyo after 10 years, and this is the hotel that i chose to stay in - it was the best choice. The hotel is budget friendly but is quite comfortable and really convenient! Most of all, their staff (at the reception) are the friendliest and one of the most helpful i've ever met. And indeed, that's the reason why i even bothered to write my very first review on tripadvisor (yeah, i'm one of the lazy ones who just read and then read some more). I only stayed in Tokyo for 2 nights, the first night i spent in Mt. Fuji summit (which isn't exactly Tokyo). LOL. The second night at Nishitetsu Inn, Shinjuku. The hotel is located very conveniently along the main road a few minutes walk from the busy and quite confusing Shinjuku Station. There are several convenience stores around the area, a McDonald's on the other side of the road, a Cafe at the first floor, and a subway about 2 minutes away. Actually, unless you have a ton of luggage you can skip the subway and just walk along the main road towards Shinjuku Station. Since it's along the road, it's very easy to find - plus the building has an orangey brick-colored design, so it sort of stands out. The room is well maintained, clean and comfortable. It's the typical size for most hotel rooms in Japan which tend to be small but not at all cramped. Of course, i was travelling solo and didn't bring a large luggage - so i found the size quite good. Also, the bathroom is quite nice and roomy. Don't expect any nice view from your window, though. It's surrounded by other buildings, and busy roads. The sound-proofing is quite good though, so i didn't have trouble getting sleep. The reception area is also quite nice, spacious with a bright and airy feel, and well staffed. Speaking of - they have one of the friendliest and most helpful staff i've ever met. They'd always politely greet you with a smile and the check-in/out was smooth and fast. Not all of them can speak English but they seem to always have at least one staff that can and would gladly help you out. I have to give a shout-out to Wada-san whom has helped me a lot during my stay with them. (i seriously hope i got his name right). On my climb to Mt. Fuji i have lost my wallet and he helped A LOT in trying to get it back. He contacted the police, several branches of 7-11, train stations and bus stations. As my Japanese isn't really all that good - he was the one to explain, write down details, hunt down contacts all the while trying to understand my broken Nihongo. Good news is, with the help of another friend of mine in Shinjuku i eventually found my wallet. I didn't get to personally say thank you to Wada-san, though. So, if any of the other staff or admin is reading this please give my utmost, most-heartfelt THANK YOU to Wada-san. I'm giving a 5-star mainly for his help. btw, i booked through booking.com which was really convenient because it doesn't tie you up with a specific credit card (remember my dilemma of losing my wallet containing almost all my credit cards). upon check-in, you can use the same card from booking.com, or use another card or even pay cash. also, the rooms don't have Wi-Fi, only ethernet cable connection but you can always borrow a Wi-Fi router from the reception for FREE. It's very easy to setup (basically just plug it in) and they come with English instructions. Lastly, it's close to the "LOVE" sculpture and the Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building. At night walk along the main road, past Shinjuku station you'd see how bright and active the night-life is in this area of the city.

I would recommend it- for shopping ( big mall around) eating( nice restaurants around)There is a nice coffee shop inside de hotel for breakfast and pretty good icecreamAll the convenience stores are less than 2 min walk

Second trip to Japan and had to spend a night at the Nishitetsu Inn since my other preference was not available. Rooms were comfortable with polite efficient service. Did not partake in any of the amenities or services.

It is close to Shinjuku (5 big blocks) station but not in the busy part of the area. Not much nice restaurants or nice shops on close blocks. It guess it is an offices part of the area. There is a 7 eleven just next to it that helped for breakfast and snacks! The staff really tryed to help us but spoke poor English. The room was very small but I guess that is a Japanese standard. The bed was very hard. No closet, only a few hangers. They gave us a small router to install so the room had good wifi. There is a small laundry on the 7th floor that helped a lot! Very clean.

We enjoyed this hotel very much though the room is really small. I would like thank the staff for helping me reserve highway bus tickekts and provide other useful information! Thank you very much! The location of this hotel is perfect, quiet near the nishi shinjuku station. Also if you take the JR lines, it would take you less than 15min walking there. I think a room with 2 beds is better as rooms in Japan are really small.

conveniently located , 100 m from metro station and < 1km form the huge JR/metro station off Shinjuku, the hotel has free wifi, and very kind staff. Rooms are standard small room, as common in tokyo, and they are clean. Reccomanded

The hotel is of good service, very convenient to go from nishi shijuku station. The room is quite small, but it's in Tokyo, so I should not complain. Maybe it's better to order a twin room (more spacious than double room, I think). It's quiet, staff are enthusiastic and helpful. They did not speak very good English, but able to communicate, that's enough. There are minimart and small resto besides, very convenientI would expect the hotel to put a better instruction on how to get to the hotel from the shinjuku station, it would be really helpful

We did not enjoy this hotel. The staff spoke almost zero English except for one person who refused to step in and help us out with directions until I insisted that I speak with someone who could speak English. As it turned out he was standing right there the whole time. He waited until I was angry and frustrated before he stepped up. Bad service. The hotel is a long, long long way from the main train station though the staff insisted we could walk there. Wrong. The hotel is three stops up the subway from the main huge train station at Shinjuku. They don't tell you that, they kept saying we could walk. No way, not with luggage. There was no drinking water in the room and it took three people to explain to me that there were vending machines on the 5th and 10th floor. This could not be explained to me over the phone, I had to go downstairs to get this answer. I would never stay here again. We asked for restaurant recommendations and no one had a clue. It was just impersonal. I guess if you're familiar with Japan and can speak some Japanese or if you're on business and can afford to get around in taxis, then it's fine. But compared to other places in Tokyo I don't see the advantage of staying here at all.

The hotel is well located near Shinjuku station. It's very clean, quiet and the size of our room was large (which was unexpected for Tokyo). There are many restaurants and all kind of shops around. The breakfast is not included but it's easy to do your own in the room.

the location is very near the Shinjuku Station West Exit, friend staff, the size of the room is enough, many restaurants very near and many good and chance, and many shop near the station, do not choose the near metro station it's better to go at the station Shinjuku

The Location is just 7 to 10 minutes by Walk from Shinjuku Station West Exit If you Turn right just After the exit, otherwise you could miss the way.The booking possibilities do not show the rooms available clearly I ordered a non Smoking room an got a Smoking room.The size of the room in m² is mentioned.However WS like ( wide Single) is Not clearly explanied.Because I am offen in Japan.I plan to be there again.

It's well located but the room are too little and there is no breakfast includedPersonal is sympathic and there is Mac Donald and subway right next to the hôtelThere is no other TV Channel than japanese neither

Very friendly staff, great location, very firm bed. Clean and simple. Typically small Japanese style room. Did not have breakfast buffet, but there is a small coffee shop right off the lobby for a la carte purchases.

THe position of the Nishitetsu Inn Shinjuku is extremely convenient as hundred meter in walking distance from the Red Metro line (Marunouchi Line) stop Nishishinjuku (M07).Next stop Shinjuku (M08), an important node in the metro grid and, also, a railway station (arrival point from Narita Airport).This is the perfect entry point for visiting Japan!Also the hotel has good Western standard, very close to what we are searching in a Business hotel!I would recommend this hotel to everyone as extremely clean, comfortable and in an excellent position.

clean, convenient and very kind & helpfull staffcomputers an printer on self service, thanks !! very helpfull to print a boarding passjust a question : why do not include the breakfast ?it seems there was a swimming pool : if yes, what a shame we were not aware!!

The hotel sucks, room is super small - Japanese room.The worst thing is that the checkout time is 10 am. We haven't wakened up, the front desk called in and threatened to charge another thousands yen if not check out before 10am

Clean, great location in the heart of Shinjuku, free wifi. Air conditioning which is a must. English spoken by desk staff. Rooms are small but assume that is normal. Get a double. Buffet breakfast available. Would stay again.

I stayed at a couple of hotels in Tokyo and this one was nice and roomy. If you need wifi just ask at reception and they will give you a wifi router to plug into the ethernet cable behind the TV and you are good to go (full instructions given on a sheet too with pictures). Not so easy to find as their large sign outside is in Japanese. You can only see the name in English when you get close to the hotel. I found it by remembering the shape of the hotel as shown in a picture in Trip Advisor. It has quite a distinctive shape.

Very helpful staff who speaks english well enough for you to get your requests across. Had to change the length of the reservation for one person and it was no problem. Rooms were quite spacious and nice. View was straight into another building but you can just shut the shutters if you prefer that. 7-10 minutes walk to Shinjuku-station, about 2 to nishishinjuku makes the location great. I would say I am very likely to come back for my next trip to tokyo

A nice place to stay, close to the station. Room ok size, clean bathroom.Good value cafe downstairs for a morning much and a cup of coffee. Nice touch to have extra toiletries by the lifts.It is a bit difficult to find coming from JR Shinjuku stn, so a bit more guidance would be helpful. It is close to a diff subway stop but you dont know that until you get to the place.

Good and helpful staff, operating 24 hours making it easy for late arrivals (such as midnight). Clean and relaxing conditions, comfortable accommodation and felt like home! Good location, close to JR station and definitely very very close to subway (M07stop) with plenty of convenient stores nearby.

Even the hotel was located on a main road but it was conveniently located with the amenities that you could want at your doorstep. My room is a good size for one person & also very well priced. I had self service laudromat & vending on my floor. It was located away from the main road so it was nice & quiet which allowed a good nights sleep. As would expect the staff were very friendly & helpful. Also loved the fact that there was a cafe on the ground floor where it served decent coffee & had a western selection of breakfast & snacky treats. Also conveniently located near the hotel was a 24hr 7-11 & the Lumine Est entrance of Shinjuku was only a 10 min walk making it easy to get the Narita Express as well metro & regional trains. Finally well priced hotel where I would definitely stay again if I'm in that neck of the woods.

I usually stay here on business. The hotel is right on the main road and not too far from Shinjuku train station and one block from Nishi Shinjuku subway station. The rooms are small! I can barely open my full size suitcase and there are no closests or drawers. There is a place to hang clothes by the door, but not a lot of space. I always have to ask for a few more hangers. There is a mini fridge and free Internet hookup, but not WiFi, so I am good with the computer but out of luck with my tablet. The bed is a bit on stiff side which I like. There is also a small desk and TV with a small window looking at the neighboring building. The staff speaks a little bit of English and most everything is translated to English and Korean. There is a new bakery on the ground floor, a McDonalds across the street and a lot of convenience stores in both directions. If you are okay with small rooms, then this is a good choice. The pictures on the website are accurate.

I stayed one night here and while it was a bit off the 'beaten path' it was in a quieter area of town and was therefore very peaceful. The hotel staff was very helpful, they offer wired internet, but will also provide a wireless router to you if you need it. The hotel was clean, the room small, but that was expected. Overall it was a fine place to stay, a really great place from which to access all areas of Tokyo

Basic accomidation, though still value for Money. Great location for anyone who wants to explore Shinjitsu. Helpful and friendly staff. Would recomend the basic room to anyone that is looking for a base to explore the city.

Daniel E
Bowraville, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: I only can recommend this hotel, I really enjoyed the room after my long journey　to Tokyo.I have trusted the reviews, they are already written in tripadvisor and booking.com and I thank to them who spended time to write them. So I must admit, it is a little bit hard to find, if you do not read kanji, but everywhere are maps to look where you are and people are very friendly to help. So it is only 5-10minutes away from the Shinjuku train station. (with heavy luggage use the elevator at the Shinjuku tower to the second floor and go along the footbridge to cross the street without any problems. The hotel is next to a police department and a 7eleven)I liked the St. Marc Cafe at the basefloor, very delicious =)So, I will come again, thank you very much.

It's a business hotel located in Shinjuku, a very animated area in Tokio. Clean, calm, helpful staff, good price...The only disappointment is bedrooms are too small but it is normal in Japan!Highly recommended to visit Tokio!!

My wife and I recently went to Japan on vacation. We stayed in the Nishitetsu Inn for three nights in a twin room. The room was reasonably large for a Japanese hotel, and was very clean. They had plenty of amenities, and the location was quite good. It is a little hard to find at first, but is reasonably close to the Shinjuku train station, and is about a block away from a subway stop. It is a few blocks from the center of activity, but that isn't all bad. There are at least two convenience stores nearby, and the McDonald's is across the street.The staff did not have very good English, but they worked hard to be as helpful as they could. There is a Starbucks in the lobby, and there was free wired internet in the room. We would definitely stay in this hotel again if we return to Japan. For the money, I don't think that you will do any better.

The hotel is in a fantastic location, less than 10 mins walking from one of the many entrance to Shinjuku station, approximately 15 mins from Kabukicho, Golden Gai etc. Really, you couldn't ask for a better location!The rooms are on small side but they are perfectly fine, the reception staff is very friendly and speaks very good English. The restaurant downstairs offers really great prices for lunch (but then again, Tokyo has like millions of places where to eat).My only small issue wasn't with the hard bed (that is what I loved the most to be honest!) but with the aircon system. Unfortunately it is pretty old and we had one night where the air wasn't coming out almost at all.Except that, I would surely suggest this great hotel and I will surely be back there again.

Absolutely wonderful hotel. The staff, location and overal comfort were wonderful and everything we would expect (and more) from the country and it's people. There is a lovely cafe in the foyer which was always a great way to start the day and the Metro is metres away. I would stay here again and would recommend it! Such a cozy and pleasant hotel I find myself thinking of it as one of the joys of Tokyo as it was my first real taste of the city after getting of the Narita express.

This hotel is of fantastic value. The location is perfect, the staff friendly, and the rooms clean. For this price and location it is almost impossible finding a better place in Tokyo. It is a 5 minute walk to Shinjuku station, it is next to 24/7 convenience stores and places to eat like Matsuya and Yoshinoya. It can be a bit loud with the window open but that's normal in the centre of the biggest city in the world.

Nishitetsu Inn was a great place to stay whilst in Tokyo. The beds were a bit hard, but we didn't really sleep much so it wasn't an issue! I would recommend this hotel because they were helpful, the staff spoke good English, and it was clean. The location in Shinjuku was also perfect for us. The only disappointment was getting a massage service through the hotel. It was a waste of money and not enjoyable. The lady was nice enough, but the experience was not relaxing.

For me visiting Tokyo for the first time, this was the ideal place to go shopping, connect via the metro to all main attraction as well as nightlife.The hotel itself offers quite basic stuff. It is clean and rather quiet despite being on a busy street. The coffee shop in the lobby has excellent treats and coffee to start a busy day.I will definately recommend for anyone looking for a place within the budget range of this hotel.

I always look at Trip Advisor and chose my hotels after reading the trip advisor information.Was not disappointed with this Hotel, great location easy to find. Safe place to be plenty to see and do. You will not be disappointed in this Hotel, helpful staff nice coffee shop at the Entrance to this Hotel.

After working on a congress in Kyoto our group goes on sightseeing through Japan. In Tokyo we stayed at this nice hotel which we booked over booking.com. As I had no idea where Shinjuku is, It was the right desission. Nishitetsu Inn is a verry moderm, cofortable and best located hotel for a moderate price. There is no wireless in the rooms, but you can rent for free a small router, so you also have wireless in the room. TV is only japanese, but who cares on TV at holidays? The inn is located between Shinjuku JR Station and Metro Station Nishinjuku. The tower of the metroplitain government of Tokyo is nearby. There you have a famous view over the city for free! In the hotel is a small bakery located. At -1 is a japanese restaurant where you can also can get a japanese breakfast (buffet) for at least 1000 YEN. In total: If again in Tokyo, the Nishitetsu Inn will be our favorite!

From the moment I stepped into the hotel till the day I checked out 8 days later the friendliness, helpfulness and cheerfulness of the staff never waned. The housekeeping staff went the extra mile to help me get my outfits ironed when I was not able to use the iron they lent me.There were many instances when the front office staff, especially Mr Miru, went out their way to teach me how to use the public phone & the wifi router to make phone calls.ju Overall, I was most satisfied with my stay at Nishitetsu Inn even though the room was small.

Warm welcome, nice staffs, good location, not so crowded, nice ambient, very good food and excellent hot spring and also have outdoor.U can call the hotel to pick u up at Gora station or cable car station.

the Hotel is well located in Shinjuku just 10 minutes walk to where everything. The rooms are small but have everything one may need. Has fast wi-fire but you will need to ask the front desk for the plug in router in order to connect. For a first visit it was not easy to find the hotel but once you get to it it's very convenient. I do strongly recommend this hotel for service, value and location. I was there alone in a single room and that was fine for one person, not sure how bigger the doubles are.

I stayed ifor 5 nights. I came via the NEX. It was quite tough to find the right exit at Shinjuku station. After we found the right one at the west exit, we have to walk for 10 to 5 mins to get to the hotel. We had baggage with us so it was not the easiest walk but manageable. Convenience store is right beside the hotel. There is a subway station very close to the hotel, less than 5 mins walk from the hotel and the station is 1 stop away from shinjuku station. Room wise is quite small but clean and well equipped.

Excellent location - close to Shinjuku Stn, and right above Nishishinjuku stn. Easy to reach, & front desk is welcoming and answers all questions.Rooms are small, but everything is provided. The rooms would be tight for a couple with 2 suitcases, but was great for me as a lone traveller.The hotel is well kept, and service is excellent !

Two 24 hour convenient stores just a few yards away in case you get that midnight hunger for a snack or drink. The double room was just enough space with it's own modern bathroom and all the amenities you need including complimentary toothbrush and toothpaste. Considering the moderate price of the room it's feels like a more higher end hotel room. Clean, comfortable and great room service. For a business traveler or like me the casual visitor than this is just perfect.

Staff service is good but the WIFI in the room doesn't work. Nearby to the main bus station and the train station. The rooms are clean. There are plenty of restaurants and convenient stores within the vicinity of the hotel. At the ground floor is a cafe that serves good coffee and pastries and sandwiches.

So friendly, so helpful, very nice clean rooms, good price, amazing location. I was very impressed with this place. There's not much more you can ask for in a hotel. Especially in this location at this price. Short walk to all the madness of Shinjuku with great restaurants all around, and the most connected train station in Tokyo just 5min walk away. I'll stay here again... mos def.

Convenient Location:- From Narita, you can take the Airport Limo that brings you to Hilton Hotel - about 5 mins walk from this hotel.- Long distances bus station to Osaka/Kyoto(Willer express) - less than 10 mins walk (at Sumitomo building). We hired a cab as it was raining and it costs JPY7100.- Nishi Shinjuku metro station is less than 500metres away. It is 2 stations to Shinjuku JR (15-20 mins walk away) where Odakyu Express to Hakone and Mt Fuji can be boarded here.- 3 convenient stalls (7-Eleven, AM-PM, Lawson) within 100-200 metres left and right from hotel.- McDonalds opposite of hotel. Yoshinoya (Japanese beef bowl house) 200 metres away.Room size though small but enough space for 2 people, impressed with the cleanliness and tidiness of the room.All hotel receptionists were kind, approachable and helpful in providing information on location, directions, maps and most of them are able to converse in English. One of them even helped us flagged the taxi on a rainy day and sheltered us to the taxi.Cons:- No wifi in the room, however it is available in the lobby. You can sit there for hours and you are left undisturbed.- No cool air-condition in room, only heater when we were there in April. It can get a little stuffy in the night and the only 1 window of the room needs to be opened - where you can hear some traffic noises from the main road - but not too loud to disturb our sleep.

This hotel is good for me to just travel alone and i am so happy to accommodate here. location is good with just 6-10 mins from Shinjuku Station and 1 mins to metro station. Rooms is not big but this is standard size in Tokyo. just the air-con is too warm for me.....

Average might overstate it a little. Having no wifi in the room was a problem for us. I was irked by the refusal to sell me a cup of coffee to go from the breakfast/dining room in the morning, but I survived with a cup from the 7-11 next door.

The staff had poor English, were totally inflexible ans bordering in an arrogant attitude. The non smoking floors were not enforced so my floor though non smoking smelt like a stale ashtray. Breakfast was a rort and only Japan cuisine in an underground basement, after buying a breakfast voucher from the desk staff I discovered the breakfast totally inedible and the desk staff would not refund my voucher which I had only bought a minute before. Basically the hotel was a bad experience to me because of the poor service, bad restaurant, arrogant desk staff and stench of the room.

The hotel is very well located. It is very agreable to be right in the middle of the city, with everything buzzling around. Otherwise, the hotel is a bit expensive for its quality but it seems to be the case of all hotels in Tokyo. I want to underline the kindness of all the Japanese people. They shoul be a modele for Europeans people.

The location is great 7 blocks from Shinjuku station and another station connecting 1 block away, very convenient. Good service, handy rooms tight, for 1 person ok, for 2 maybe too small but clean. internet wifi in the room. One night didn't work but the remaining 3 nights ok.

It is nearby a metro station (Nishi Shinjuku) and about 20 minutes walk to Shinjuku station, check-ins are from 3pm, bedrooms and bathrooms are clean. However, the bed is quite hard and can be a bit uncomfortable,

Very nice hotel, well situated near Shinjuku station. Room is practical, calm and very clean.The employees at reception don't speak much english whiwh is a bad point unfortunately.I recommend this hotel.

Good location, about 10 min walk to JR Shinjuku station. Wifi only available in the lobby, not in rooms. Friendly staff with basic English. Lots of malls, restaurants & convenience stalls around the area with a McD just opposite the road for those who want a change from Japanese food.

Stayed 3 nights in April 2013. However, it was unfortunate that throughout our stay, there were problems with their a/c and the room was very warm. On the first night, rang reception for a fan, however, was told that they ran out of fans. After numerous phone calls to reception, advising that it was impossible to sleep, they finally managed to bring us a mini-fan, which helped a little. Had to open the window as well, however it wasn't of much help since a fraction of the window could only be opened and not much wind could come through. Management should consider adjusting their window setting so that the window can be opened wider, for a cooler room. Apart from the above, location-wise, it was easily accessible to the train and subway station, restaurants, cafe, and mini-mart. Price-wise, it was reasonable and room was clean.Staff helpful and courteous despite our grouchy attitude towards them when we could not get the fan initially. For this I have to give a belated apology to the staff/s concerned, since its not their fault and they had to bear the brunt of our grouchiness.

The hotel is near to the train and subway station, there is restaurants, café, minimarket around.The room is confortable and clean, the staff is helpful. The internet OK.It:s a nice place to stay.I really recommend it.

My first arrival at shinjuku station, there`s a huge map near bus terminal showing the name of this inn with romaji word. It was a little bit difficult to seek this inn among buildings at night. So if you go back to inn at night, be aware and remember the exact location was.

This is a safe bet generic "hotel", well located next to trains, shopping and restaurants.The check in is efficient and friendly enough yet did not have much luck getting misc infos in english ... The room and bathroom was quite small and very clean in the japanese norm. It was quiet.The TV is strictly japanese ...annoyingly the CNN channel was dubbed ! wifi in lobby but not in rooms, however a free ethernet connection to the web for a laptop.a breakfast was available but not in the hotel itself .... Mac Donald was across the street but a better choice is one of the many local food bars seemingly opened all night...While the train station is 8 mn away walking . one can get confused by the indirect paths to get there.!

I was so glad that I had acted on recommendations from other trip advisor users and booked this hotel for my stay. Firstly the location is excellent. It is 2 mins on foot from Nishi-Shinjuku subway station on the red line - a direct line from Tokyo station and the Shinjuku subway/JR interchange. I found this really easy as a base to get around to everywhere I needed to go. Its also a 8 min walk to the airport bus service requiring no trains or stairs etc. If you are using this service to get from the airport to the hotel I suggest you print off a map otherwise it could be slightly confusing the first time but fine with a map/directions. I wouldn't recommend a taxi from the bust stop to the hotel during the day - it’s a very busy area, it’s probably just as quick to walk it. The other great thing about the location is its surrounded by cafes, convenience stores and eateries. I didn't book breakfast with the hotel and really didn't need to because there were numerous options around. It’s also just 5 minutes on foot from the Shinjuku area proper - the department stores, electronic stores and small bars and restaurants. Once you are in this area (just down the road from the hotel) you get a sense of the 'real' Tokyo - tall buildings, lots of neon lights. The hotel itself was extremely good value. I booked a single room expecting it to be tiny. It wasn't. I had a double bed, decent sized room and bathroom (by asia standards). It was very clean and not dated at all. The flow of air was great, never felt stuffy. The rooms include a kettle, dehumidifier, green tea (no coffee but you can get that from the shops next door), a fridge, flat screen, the bathroom had all the regular products plus tooth brush. There were also slippers and a night gown. Because I had a single room there was only 1 pillow when I arrived, however on request they gave me a second and a blanket. All in all the room was really comfortable and I have no complaints. The only standard things missing were a safe and english TV channals. I used the safe at reception which was fine and very easy to do. The last two hotels I'd stayed at in Japan had either no English channal or only one. So at this point I didn't care. The hotel service was great - again no complaints. The front desk staff were super helpful. There is the use of the computers and internet in the reception area for free - a relief after having to pay 1 dollar for 15 mins at another hotel. The lobby area is large and clean. There are plenty of front desk staff so I never had to wait more than a couple of minutes to speak to someone. And whenever I asked for something in my room it came within 5 minutes. Would definitely recommend for solo travellers as I was, a very safe and convenient location to explore Tokyo from plus good size single room.

This hotel is excellently located for sightseeing, shopping if you dare, great restaurants and the staff is very helpful. It was a bit difficult communicating in english but somehow we always got there in the end. Also, I met lots of other guests in the lobby (using wi-fi) who were travelling throughout JapanThe rooms are very clean and my single room had adequate space. I was located on the 14th floor and opened the window at night so it was nice and cool, also quiet.There's a great Japanese buffet breakfast that's also good value to try at least once.I would most definitely stay here again.

Very central, clean, quiet, small rooms.Extremely hard matress though.Although there wasn't wifi internet the front desk loaned us (for free) a little device the plugged into the internet cable and gave us our own little wifi which was very helpful indeed.A great little place to stay and close to all the shijuku fun.

We stayed at this hotel for 6 nights March-April 2013 and had a very good experience.Smooth check in/check out. You just drop your card in a box if you are in a hurry and doesn't need to pay anything extra (like rent of a laptop)All the staff we spooked to were friendly and helpful when asking for help or advice. The size of the room was big enough for us 2 with two large suitcases. And it was a good thing to not feel claustrophobic when taking a shower. For us, this was to biggest room so far in Tokyo. The Nishi-Shinjuku subway station is about 2 min from the hotel and it takes about 10-15 min from the big Shinjuku station depending from which exit you go out to.I would recommend the A18 exit at the Shinjuku station if you are not carrying to much luggage and the take the overpass so you go over to the other side of Meiji dori street. Go in a west direction, pass a Lawson convenient store and when you pass the 7/11 store you are about 20 meter from the hotel. Just down the road you will find many café for having a breakfast and Shinjuku is a great place to stay at if you like to shop and eat. Easy access to rest of Tokyo from either Nishi-Shinjuku station or the Shinjuku station. We also liked to have the 7/11 ATM very close so we didn't have to worry about taking out money using a foreign card.I would return to the hotel since it was good value for money, clean room, traffic at night very quite, and the hotel is in a good location in Shinjuku.

The rooms are a bit small but that is the norm with Tokyo.The room was very clean and comfortable.The staff were friendly too.The hotel is about a 2 minute walk from the subway and next door to 7/11.Shinjuku is a great area to stay in.

I stayed a week here while in Tokyo in October.The room I got was a little cramped, but ok -after I'd stoved away the suitcase.The good:+ Plenty of power outlets+ Big bed actually and a nice, huge pillow+ Clean+ Good cleaning-service+ Shampoo and soap dispensers in the bathroom+ Internet (wired)+ Very close to Nishi-Shinjuku on the Marunochi line and even a short walk from Shinjuku station itself.+ Not excactly cheap, but ok price for the location and the short booking I made.The not so good:- Internet is wired only (WiFi only in the lobby), so you need to pop down to yodobashi and buy a little wireless router if you plan to use your "iUnits".- No check-in before 15:00, they state this clearly, but it's still annoying, especially after spending 15 hours traveling and arriving very early in the morning in Japan.- Staff (via phone from the room) was a little bit so-so in English, daytime staff in the lobby spoke English well enough.- No known shuttle-service to / from Narita airport. Upon request, they simply stated that they did not have this and gave me a (very complicated) pamphlet over bus-times and pointed towards the nightmarish Shinjuku-station. (I ended up traveling with Narita express, after spending half a day inside Shinjuku-station to learn the way from the subway to the express trains instead)- It can be a little busy with ambulances, because it's located not far from a hostpital, probably depends a little where your room is located.All in all; It's convenient, clean and practical and a good hub, from which you can travel around the city and look around.

This is an excellent hotel in the centre of Tokyo, just about 100m away from the madness that is Shinjuku.The best way to get to the hotel is take the subway to Nishi-Shinjuku Metro Station and walk about 70 meters. This is far simpler than trying to get out the correct exit from Shinjuku.The staff speak Enlish and are always willing to help. The hotel has a couple of internet linked PC in the lobby whihc are free to use all day long.The rooms are a good size. I had a single room which nevertheless contained a large (double bed). The rooms and hotel are super clean and modern. It does not have gym or swimming pool, just the basics. There are plenty of shops open all night to get snacks and drinks.Perfect for someone on a limted sudget.

The location is the best feature of this hotel, I spend The night in here in transit to China, The hotel is located near The shinjuku station (Narita express train arrives here), it is easy to find, and the area sourrounding is very alive. Small room, clean, enought for one night.

Excellent location, just a short walk from Nishi-Shinjuku Metro Station. They have a ladies-floor, (14th floor) which I requested for my stay. That floor comes with the washer/dryer and vending machine in a room, which requires the access card to enter. I got the double-bed room, which is considered spacious for a single person. Room is very clean and bed very comfy to sleep in. They offer disposable slippers and also gives sachets of shiseido cleansing oil. The best thing is that the room offers a foot massager! A God-sent after a crazy day of sight-seeing/shopping.
It is all about location, and this hotel fits the bill.. I was there during the emperor b day and prices are slightly higher than normal .. Well it is still a great place for business hotel standard.

Japanese business hotels have always been said to be small, but this particular was exceeded my expectation. It's not spacious like what you would get from the 5,6-star chains, but I consider my double room very reasonably sized.Our room was very clean and the furniture looked very new. We had clean towels, sheets and a very comfortable bed. The pillow was very interesting because it's double layered. One side is soft and other side have some kind of beads in it. Soap, shampoo and conditioner are provided in the bathroom from a pump dispenser. There is a deep bathtub. Shower cap, shower scrub, comb, cotton buds, cleansing oil are provided on a tray by the lift lobby on the ground floor. Slippers and odour spray are also provided in our room.The bathroom has a low ceiling, and one may feel claustrophobic inside, but there is enough space to move around. The toilet bowl is automated.There is Internet connection available in the room but not WIfi. If you have a laptop you will be able to hook up to the Internet via the cable provided in the room. If you're using iPhone, iPad, iTouch, you can try to rent a MyFi device at the airport. It costs 1575 Yen per day for me. The battery life is only about 4 hours max.There is no room service although there is a cafe located by the entrance of the hotel. Coupons for breakfast at this cafe can be found in the drawer in our room but we didn't make use of it because there are many food options in Tokyo.It is abut a 2 minute walk to the Nishi-Shinjuku station which is on the Marunouchi Subway Line and about an 8 minute walk to the main Shinjuku JR Line.If you choose to walk to the Shinjuku JR Line, you will pass by Bic Camera which is a big electronics shop. You also have Keio, Odakyu there, which are big shopping malls. The Airport Limousine will take you to Shinjuku JR Station area from the airport, after which if you take a taxi to this hotel, it will cost 710 Japanese Yen, which is the starting fare. Because cars can only go one way, the taxi will have to make a big round to get to the hotel. So I suggest if you are not carrying a lot of luggage to try to walk there instead.McDonalds is located right across the street and there are several convenience stores located here. 7 Eleven, Lawsons and Natural Lawsons (which stocks organic products) are almost side by side. Some of the staff do not speak much English, but some do, depending on who is on shift. They are very professional and accommodating.
